Column: 615

MERGER (SINGAPORE/FEDERATION OF MALAYA)
(White Paper)


2.32 p.m.

    Order read for resuming adjourned debate on Amendment [21st November, 1961] to Question [20th November, 1961].

Column: 616



    'That, whereas it has always been the avowed objective of all nationalists of Malaya to achieve the reunification of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya and to remove the artificial division created by the British by their policy of "divide and rule", this House affirms and declares that the first objective of all true patriots of Malaya is to achieve the reunification of these two territories in a merger of Singapore with the Federation of Malaya'.-(The Minister for Labour-Inche Ahmad Bin Ibrahim).

    Which Amendment was,

    To leave out from "a" in the second last line to the end and insert:

    "genuine merger of Singapore with the Ayer), Federation of Malaya, with Singapore entering the Federation as the twelfth state and with all its Citizens automatically becoming Federal Citizens on Merger Day".-(Dr Lee Siew Choh).

    Question again proposed, "That the words proposed to he left out, be left out."

2.34 p.m.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P., which was once trusted by the people, has now turned the spears against the people. It threatens the people that they must accept the phoney merger proposed by the P.A.P., otherwise, the water supply will be cut off. They must not accept the true merger proposed by the Barisan Sosialis (this is what they say, Sir), otherwise, they will be disenfranchised. Sir, how threatening the words are.

    The P.A.P. leaders told the Party workers during the Anson by-election that there was no necessity for the Leftists to help the Party in Anson. They then told the people of Anson that if the P.A.P. was defeated in Anson, the Government would consider whether or not to stay in office. Owing to their refusal to rectify their past mistakes and owing to their refusal to unite with the Left-wing forces, the Party was defeated. The merger issue became a major item of open debate in the Anson by-election and the defeat of the P.A.P. in Anson clearly showed that the people had no faith in the P.A.P. The people rejected the phoney merger proposed by the PAP. Government.

Column: 617



    After this defeat of the P.A.P. in Anson, the P.A.P. leaders went wild like wild beasts. They ran to Malaya to consult the Tunku to cure their injury. They are supposed to be injured by the so-called Communists, Sir. They told the Tunku that they were injured by the so-called Communists and they also warned the Tunku that if he did not watch out, he would also be injured.

    Sir, the policy speech states that, "this dead-end is favoured by some, because they are afraid to leave security in the hands of the Central Government of a new and larger Federation." Sir, what does it mean? What does it intend to tell the people? It means that the Leftists in Singapore are opposing merger. That is not true. It intends to tell the people that merger is good for them, but the Leftists are opposing it because they are afraid of being arrested by the Central Government once merger has taken place. That is also not true. What a despicable attempt to smear the Leftists! Why do I say that, Sir? Because these Leftists had been arrested once or twice during the colonial regime, during the period that was most dangerous to them. Sir, you can ask our Ministers opposite, where were they then? In their warm beds, I think. Who were arrested?

    The P.A.P. ruling clique also said that we liked the British because we fought only for full internal self-government and not merger. My answer is this. The British come from a place outside Singapore. So is the Federation, a country that is outside Singapore. From these two, we will oppose anyone who tries to exploit us - the British and Malaya too. If the P.A.P. ruling clique purposely say that we do not want the phoney merger proposed by the P.A.P., and we are therefore anti-nationals, then I would like to inform them that we are not anti-nationals, we are anti-violence. Violence is always created by Right-wing people and colonialists. The atrocious act of Portugal in Angola, Tshombe in the Congo and the French in Algeria are clear instances. If the Government tries to sell the interests of the people, then the people will have no choice but to put the Government down before they do something to the British.

Column: 618



    The Government of Singapore said that merger between Singapore and the Federation was for rapid economic expansion and industrialisation that would bring more factories and more jobs for thousands of our young men leaving our schools and seeking employment. But the Government of Malaya said that merger between Singapore and Malaya was decided because of the fear that the Communists would turn Singapore into a base of operation against Malaya. Sir, from here, we can see that the Federation Government is not interested in the so-called merger proposed by the P.A.P. Government. What she is interested in is the internal security of Singapore, which the P.A.P. Government promised to hand over to the Federation Government. This means that the status of Singapore will remain as it is; and even worse, Singapore will remain as a self-governing State with its defence, internal security and foreign affairs transferred from the British colonial government to the Malayan Right-wing Government.

    The Government says that Singapore will seek independence through merger under conditions which will give Singapore autonomy in education and labour. Sir, this proposal is unworkable and the P.A.P. leaders know it. Singapore cannot have autonomy in education and labour if internal security is in the hands of the Federation, because the Federation will use the internal security power to interfere with the education and labour policies in Singapore.

    Sir, I am not going to elaborate any more details about how the Federation Government is going to interfere, but I can show you the case of Mr Lim Lian Geok, an educationist whose citizenship is -

    Mr David Marshall (Anson) rose -

    Mr Speaker: On a point of order?

    Mr David Marshall: Yes. I have personal knowledge of the fact that the case of Mr Lim Lian Geok is before the Federation Court of Appeal, and I would ask

Column: 619

you, Mr Speaker, Sir, whether it is proper, either according to our Standing Orders or according to the normal courtesies of Comity of nations, to mention in the Assembly a matter that is sub judice.

    Mr Speaker: If the matter is, in fact, .sub judice then, of course, it cannot be mentioned in the Assembly. I accept the information given by the Member for Anson that the matter is, in fact, sub judice, and, therefore, it cannot be mentioned in the Assembly.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I withdraw what I have said just now.

    Apart from this, will the Government in the Federation keep quiet when it sees that the Singapore education policy and labour movement are advancing to such an extent that they become entirely different from those of the Federation Government? Sir, she will not keep quiet. Will the Government in the Federation cry for a change of our education and labour policies when she does not like our ways of implementing the policies? Sir, the Federation Government will cry for a change. Due to the present education policy of the Federation, will the Chinese school students in the Federation swarm into Singapore for secondary education? They will come and Singapore cannot stop them because it is "part of Malaya". If this happens, will the Federation Government grant financial aid to Singapore for education? Can the students educated in Singapore seek employment in the Federation?

    Sir, the Tunku said at the U.M.N.O. General Assembly on 4th of November this year that merger was decided for fear of Communist activities in Singapore. Therefore, we can see from here that the Government of the Federation is not interested in economic expansion or the employment of our young men after leaving school in Singapore. Sir, you can go and read the 12 fairy tales written by our Prime Minister and which were broadcast over Radio Singapore last month. You will see how the Prime Minister of Singapore plans for the Government of the Federation to lay

Column: 620

hands on persons whom the Prime Minister does not like. He does it secretly and openly by telling the names of the so-called Communists to the Malayan Government for future action. He also plans for the Government of the Federation to interfere in the education and labour policies by saying that the communists have infiltrated into Chinese secondary schools, trade unions, cultural organisations, etc. Sir, it is a plot to sell the people and to save the ruling clique of the P.A.P.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our Party Chairman has given a very lengthy speech about the question of citizenship and merger, but it is very regrettable that citizenship, which is so important and which is the fundamental right of the people, was not broadcast over Radio Singapore to enable our people to know what has happened in this Assembly. The P.A.P. has now turned Radio Singapore into Radio P.A.P.

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: The 15-minute speech delivered by the Minister for Labour took about 30 minutes over Radio Singapore, but the 450-minute speech delivered by our Party Chairman took less than five minutes over Radio Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I think you will remember that a few years back the Chinese Chamber of Commerce fought so hard for citizenship rights for those who were not born in Singapore, and due to the effort and energy of the Chinese Chamber of Commerce particularly, and the support of the people generally, the colonial Government gave citizenship rights to the people of Singapore - those who were born outside the colony. Now many people have acquired citizenship rights and, of course, they are very happy and proud - happy because they have a say in their welfare in the Assembly and proud because they have the right to vote persons to form their own government. Now the effort of the people is to be sold to the Federation by the P.A.P. ruling clique. This citizenship right which they had fought to obtain is now to be deprived -

Column: 621



    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Read your White Paper.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: - as a result of the P.A.P. type of merger. Yes, White Paper - the P.A.P. White Paper! Their happiness is now turned into sorrow and their pride is no more. Their love for the P.A.P. has now turned into anger. That is why the P.A.P. leaders dare not go to meet the people and yet they say that they represent the people. But they need bodyguards when they go and see them!

    The P.A.P. says that in the complete merger proposed by the Barisan Sosialis, Singapore would be entitled to have 14 or 15 seats in the Central Government and that half of the Singapore citizens would be disenfranchised. This means that half of the people who are citizens born in Singapore will automatically become citizens of the Federation. This also means that these people will have the right to vote and be voted to the Central Government in the Federation. We can call this an incomplete merger. This is what the P.A.P. says. But our Barisan Sosialis stand is that all Singapore citizens - about 620,000 - must become Federal citizens automatically on Merger Day.

    Let us come to the P.A.P. merger. They said that all citizens of Singapore would not lose their citizenship rights or be disenfranchised with the P.A.P. brand of merger. But as you will see at page 4 of the Memorandum on merger, all Singapore citizens will only vote in Singapore and elect their representatives in Singapore to the Central Government.

    Sir, to put the position more clearly to the people, I shall set out my arguments in a mathematical way:

    (a) In the phoney merger of the P.A.P., we will get -

    (i) 15 seats for Singapore in the Central Government;

    (ii) Singapore citizens cannot become citizens of a larger Federation;

    (iii) all powers and privileges

Column: 622

are handed to the Federation Government.

    (b) In the incomplete merger of the P.A.P., we will get -

    (i) 15 seats for Singapore in the Central Government;

    (ii) half of the Singapore citizens will be disenfranchised;

    (iii) all powers and privileges are handed to the Federation Government; but

    (c) In the complete merger of the Barisan Sosialis, we will get -

    (i) 25 to 30 seats for Singapore in the Central Government on the basis of proportional representation;

    (ii) all Singapore citizens - about 620,000 - will automatically become citizens of Malaya;

    (iii) the powers of the State will be transferred to the Central Government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in any colony, you are sure to find the mouth-pieces of colonialism and these people are a privileged class with the colonialists who rule. They live on the blood and sweat of the majority of the people. These people with the colonialists control the Government and they call themselves representatives of the people. These so-called representatives of the people govern the people without any knowledge of the people's sufferings. What they know is the passing of a few Bills and motions for the benefit of the cornpradores and their own clique to Control the people's thinking in order to give more opportunities for themselves to exploit the people and to rule longer. What they are interested in is dancing, cocktail parties, garden parties.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I did promise not to intervene for irrelevancies, but I think this type of irrelevancy must not be allowed.

Column: 623



    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the P.A.P. leadership believe in having a good time. Like their colonial predecessors, they like to hold on to power., otherwise they would be deprived of their status in life. The people of Asia and Africa are in revolt against this mentality. What do the ruling class do? What do they care? They do not care. If you ask the ruling class about this -

    An hon. Member: Who are the ruling class?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: The P.A.P. ruling class! If you ask the ruling class about this, they will answer in this manner, "Never mind, let the poor people be the poor people, and they can go and die. Anyway, it is a free and democratic country and if they want to, they can try to rule us. They have the right to do so." This is what the ruling class will answer. Sir, such a feature is very common in those countries where the people are now trying to overthrow the ruling class. And this ruling class have never thought that the people will rise one day to revolt against them. That is why many countries and many governments have been overthrown. Having experienced that, the ruling class are becoming more fierce, ruthless and merciless. They blame the people for creating violence. Some people misunderstand and say that it is the people who create violence because they use force against the so-called Government. Who creates violence? Surely it is the ruling class. When an incident takes place, we must first find out the cause. Violence is not necessarily due to those who are involved in it. Often enough, it is due to the repression that comes from the ruling class. If the Government is good, no one will fight against it. Instead the people will support it. That is why the people will not support the P.A.P. - the P.A.P. is no good. It is because the Government uses force to suppress the people and makes them suffer so much that they have no alternative but to go against the Government.

    What I have said above can also be applied to strikes and other matters.

Column: 624

As in the case of merger, the P.A.P. is seeking to bring about a situation of greater repression.

    There are two ways by which we can overthrow a government. One is by peaceful means and the other is by force of arms.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I am afraid I am compelled to intervene in this type of speech which seems to me to be au electioneering speech. It has gone very, very far away from the motion. I think perhaps I could warn Members that if they go too far away from the motion they must expect interventions from the Chair. I think this type of speech has gone much too far away from the motion.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the people want the Government to return their mandate. The P.A.P. refuses. It therefore quickly brings up the merger issue and threatens the people by talking about imaginary consequences that will happen if merger does not take place.

    As I said above, the phoney merger of the P.A.P. is an attempt to enable the ruling class to control the people's thinking, to exploit them and to rule for a further period. The merger issue is of such vital importance that it affects everyone living in Singapore, but the P.A.P. which came into power with the support of the people does not consult them on this merger issue. Instead it tries to threaten the people and prepares to impose its own type of merger. We accuse the P.A.P. of not consulting the people. The leaders of the P.A.P. said that they would put the matter before the people after the Prime Ministers of the Federation and Singapore have settled the details on merger. Sir, this is not, the correct way of going about the matter. Merger is a national matter and concerns everyone. It is not a .party matter. The Government should have consulted the people before making any decision. It should put the matter for open debates and discussions. It should ask the trade unionists, education bodies, cultural bodies, student organisations, rural organisations, professional men and others to submit

Column: 625

their views and make suggestions. But the P.A.P. has not done so. This is the first great mistake the P.A.P. has made.

    The Legislative Assembly is a place where representatives of the people discuss matters which concern the country and the people. On the merger question, the Government should have first sought the opinion and support of the Assembly before it discussed the matter with the Tunku. The Government has not done that. Before the Tunku led the merger mission to England to discuss the Malaysia plan, he received overwhelming support from the Federal Assembly, but the P.A.P. did not ask for support from the Assembly before it went to meet the Tunku on the merger issue. This is the second great mistake the P.A.P. made. The P.A.P. Government, without consulting anyone, secretly tried to transfer all powers, privileges, rights and interests of the people of Singapore to the Federation Government. This is the third great mistake done by the P.A.P., and it is a treacherous act of the P.A.P. in trying to sell out Singapore.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): That is right.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Years ago in China, Sir, there was a General called Wu San Kwei. For his own selfish ends, he allowed the Manchurians to conquer China, and the P.A.P. is doing that.

    An hon. Member: Doing what?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Ask yourself. Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the hon. Member for Cairnhill is aware that if the P.A.P. is defeated on the merger question, the S.P.A. and the P.A.P. will be thrown into the drain to be washed away by the people, and because the hon. Member is afraid that his Party, the S.P.A., may vanish with the P.A.P., he is forced to oppose our amendment.

    An hon. Member: What about ourselves?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: The same. They are all the same, Sir, and he also criticised the P.A.P. brand of merger because he knew that if he supported it, his Party, the S.P.A., would be in the dead camp

Column: 626

of the P.A.P. If we study carefully what the hon. Member for Cairnhill has said, we will be able to find out that what he has uttered is also very much the same as that uttered by the P.A.P. leaders, both inside the Assembly.

    In conclusion. Sir, the P.A.P. and the S.P.A. are sitting on the same side as that -

    The Minister for Education (Mr Yong Nyuk Lin): Opposite side.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Same side - the thinking is the same, Sir. It is a regret that a non-communal Party like the P.A.P., when discussing the importance of citizenship rights in this Assembly, has purposely tried to cast a shadow of communal fear over our Malay brothers both in Singapore and in the Federation.

    The duty of the Government in ruling a multi-racial country such as ours is to create harmony and unity among all races and not to create hatred and disunity among the races, but P.A.P. is now using this despicable method to create communal fear and to undo all the efforts which the people had put in in the past, to bring about unity to all races. I would like to remind the P.A.P. that if they want to leave a good record for the history of Singapore, then they must not attempt the sordid practice of creating communal fear.

    Sir, unity is strength. This formula can he applied to all things. It is good and wise for all peoples of all races to unite together to form a single group of people, hut this can only take place if the guardians or the leaders of the people treat them impartially. To guarantee that there is no conflict among the races, the leaders must not take the communal line. but must treat all people equally. Under the P.A.P. brand of merger. Singapore citizens share the same responsibility, but have no equal benefits, and it will only bring chaos and disunity to our country and our people. No one will benefit from it. The P.A.P. and even the ruling clique will suffer. It will be a total loss to our country. It is very interesting to see the P.A.P. leaders fighting the British colonialists with their voices in this Assembly, where there

Column: 627

are no British colonialists. They blame the British for their divide-and-rule policy but this divide-and-rule policy has already been made. It is up to the Government to mobilise the strength of the people, to persuade and force the British colonialists to accept our demand. It is only with strength that the battle can be won, but can we see the Government doing that? We can see them only creating communal hatred, creating suspicion among the races, creating fears. We can see them begging the colonial forces, the Right-wing forces, to save the P.A.P. from being drowned. Sir, when a person is in danger of drowning, he will struggle desperately and dangerously. The P.A.P. is now struggling desperately and dangerously. Sir, the Member for Kreta Ayer has said something like that; that we, the Barisan Sosialis, do not have any plan as to how the merger should take place.

    Mr Speaker: Order. May I know who the Member for Kreta Ayer is?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: I am sorry. I mean the Minister for Finance.

    How the merger should take place and how the citizens of Singapore should automatically become citizens of the Federation of Malaya.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I thought I remarked that there is a difference between reading and referring to one's notes. I ask the Member for Changi not to make it so obvious that he is reading.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: I would like to inform the Member on this merger issue. The Government has not sought the Opinion of the Opposition Parties. It is, therefore, the duty of the Government to draw up plans on this merger issue. If they want our detailed plans, the only way is for them to resign and face the people. This is the only solution. When the P.A.P. resigns, elections must, of course, be held and the Barisan Sosialis will be eager to explain clearly the meaning of merger and citizenship to the people. Let the people choose freely whether they want our Barisan Sosialis'

Column: 628

merger, or they want the sell-out plans of the P.A.P.

    As I said just now. Sir, if the P.A.P. Government wants our plans of merger, it must call an All-Party Conference to discuss the matter, or the P.A.P. must resign. The Minister for Finance said that we were a group of angry young men. Yes, angry young men, angry because the P.A.P. traitors are trying to sell out the interests of the people of Singapore; angry because the P.A.P. leaders call themselves patriots, sincere democrats, nationalists, 100 per cent socialists, and yet they do things similar to those done by traitors.

    The Minister for Culture said that the Barisan Sosialis were afraid of merger for fear of getting into trouble when merger takes place. He indicated that the Barisan Sosialis leaders are afraid of being arrested by the Central Government. Sir, in a phoney merger, the sell-out has taken place. This type of utterance is meant to fool the people into believing that the Barisan Sosialis is selfish. I would like to inform the Member that his false statements cannot blind the people. The people will not believe him. The people may believe him if he had been sleeping in a hard bed in Changi Gaol. But he has never slept there; he has been sleeping in a warm soft bed in his own sweet and comfortable home.

    Mr Speaker: Order. I am trying to avoid this type of language. These personalities should never creep in in a debate in this Chamber.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: During the colonial regime our Barisan Sosialis leaders were thrown into gaol for years.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): There was no Barisan Sosialis!

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Yes, our Barisan Sosialis leader.

    An hon. Member: Where were you?

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, where was I? I was a student in Beatty Secondary School, and I did help the P.A.P. to contest the elections. Ask the Member for Tampines. I was a student.

Column: 629



    During the colonial regime our Barisan Sosialis leaders were thrown into gaol for years. They were put in gaol by the colonialists just because they fought for the interests of the people.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): If it were not for the people, they would still be there!

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: The P.A.P. leaders then were in Cameron Highlands and Fraser's Hill. The Minister for Culture said that it was true that Singapore citizens could not go to the Federation to contest the elections: but it was equally true that Federation citizens cannot come to Singapore to contest the elections. Only fools believe such words. Federation citizens cannot come to Singapore to contest the elections, but they lose nothing. Instead they gain. They gain control over Singapore. Singapore citizens cannot go to the Federation to contest the elections, but they lose all the rights and privileges which they are now enjoying. He also said that Singapore citizens have the right to elect representatives to the Federal Parliament. But the Member must remember that the so-called citizens are only those who can speak English and the national language; only persons who can speak English and the national language have the right to be voted to sit in the Federal Parliament, Sir.

    An hon. Member: Change it!

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: We will try to change it.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta): The Barisan Sosialis can change it.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Yes, we can change it.

    Mr Speaker: Order. Sometimes it is pleasant to hear a lady's voice. But perhaps the lady will contain herself.

    Mr Teo Hock Guan: Sir, what this indicates is that Singapore citizens will be deprived of their rights completely in one way or another. The people of

Column: 630

Singapore have the right to vote but they have not the right to be voted because they are not English and Malay speaking.

    Sir, the Minister for Health and Law has quoted many words of law in order to misled the people.
